stem: The infection control nurse is reviewing the serology profiles for four clients. Based on the documentation, match each serological marker with the correct clinical status.

tabs.title: Patient Information
tabs.content:
Patient 1: 24-year-old male recently exposed to Hepatitis B via a needlestick injury; currently asymptomatic.
Patient 2: 30-year-old female, healthcare student who completed the Hepatitis B vaccine series last month.
Patient 3: 45-year-old male with chronic jaundice and fatigue for 6 months.
Patient 4: 28-year-old female who had Hepatitis A as a child and is now fully recovered.

tabs.title: Serology Profile
tabs.content:
PatientPositive MarkerNegative Marker
Patient 1HBsAg (Surface Antigen)Anti-HBs (Surface Antibody)
Patient 2Anti-HBs (Surface Antibody)HBsAg (Surface Antigen)
Patient 3HBsAg and HBeAgAnti-HBc (Core Antibody), Anti-HBs (Surface Antibody)
Patient 4IgG anti-HAVIgM anti-HAV

tabs.title: Liver Function Tests
tabs.content:
Patient 3: ALT 850 U/L, AST 720 U/L.
Patients 1, 2, and 4: ALT/AST within normal limits.

rows.text: IgG anti-HAV Positive, IgM anti-HAV Negative

rationale.correct: A positive Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) indicates the presence of the virus, signifying an acute infection or infectious state (r1). A positive Hepatitis B surface antibody (Anti-HBs) alone, in the absence of other antibodies, typically indicates immunity acquired through vaccination (r2). A positive IgM anti-HAV indicates a recent or acute Hepatitis A infection (r3). A positive IgG anti-HAV with a negative IgM anti-HAV indicates past infection and subsequent immunity to Hepatitis A (r4).
clinicalPearls: HBsAg: Surface Antigen. If present, the virus is present.
Anti-HBs: Surface Antibody. Indicates immunity, usually from vaccination.
IgM: Indicates acute or recent infection.
IgG: Indicates past infection and immunity.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming a positive antibody always indicates immunity from vaccination.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Consider the specific antibody and the patient's history. For Hepatitis B, check for the presence of Anti-HBc (core antibody). If positive, immunity is from past infection, not vaccination.

mnemonic.title: Hepatitis Serology Markers
mnemonic.expansion: Ag = Active infection. Anti-HBs = Antibody from Surface (vaccination). IgM = Immediate infection. IgG = Gone (past infection).
